title: How Boris Johnson Fell, and What Happens Next
abstract: Britain’s prime minister said he would step down, less than three years after a landslide election victory. Here’s a guide to why he was forced out and who might succeed him.
byline: By Stephen Castle and Peter Robins

title: Glacier Tragedy Shows Reach of Europe’s New Heat
abstract: A collapse at the top of one of Italy’s tallest peaks offered the latest evidence of the deadly threat posed by rising temperatures.

title: For Foreign Fighters in Ukraine, a War Unlike Any They’ve Seen
abstract: Small groups of Western combat veterans are on the front lines, but many more with fewer skills are left trying to find a role to play.
byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Valerie Hopkins and Jane Arraf

title: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies. Single Moms Don’t Qualify.
abstract: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.

multimedia.caption: Officials have been doling out tax and housing credits, educational benefits and cash to encourage women to have more children. But a marriage prerequisite is increasingly unappealing to those who prefer to parent alone.
multimedia.copyright: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

title: Mass Funeral Deepens Mystery: Why Did 21 South African Teens Die in Tavern?
abstract: Survivors of the tragedy last month recounted in interviews the presence of a mysterious gas and then a crush to escape. Officials say the stampede didn’t kill them.
byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Zipo-zenkosi Ncokazi

multimedia.caption: Residents wept after laying flowers at the entrance to Enyobeni Tavern in East London, South Africa, where 21 teenagers died in the early hours of June 26.

title: Parents of 8-Year-Old Were Accused of Her Murder. Now, So Are 12 More People.
abstract: Elizabeth Struhs of Queensland, Australia, died in January because, according to the police, she was denied medical care.

title: China Seeks to Pre-Empt Sanctions in Case of Taiwan Clash, F.B.I. Chief Says
abstract: Looking ahead to a possible conflict, Beijing wants to shield itself from the kind of economic penalties levied against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the F.B.I. director says.

title: A Year Since a President’s Murder, Haitians Keep Waiting to Hit Rock Bottom
abstract: In the year since President Jovenel Moïse was killed, the country’s despair has deepened. Gangs now vie with the government for control.

title: Ethnic Killings in Ethiopia Add to Crisis
abstract: Allegations of a second recent ethnic massacre in the restive region of Oromia further destabilize a country already coping with civil war in a northern region.

title: France, Hoping to Weather Energy Crisis, Will Renationalize Electricity Giant
abstract: The state already has a majority stake in France’s main electricity and nuclear company. The move reflected President Emmanuel Macron’s desire to champion economic and energy sovereignty.

title: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
abstract: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.

title: For Boris Johnson, a Tumultuous Tenure Ends With a Messy Exit
abstract: The risk-taking bravado of Britain’s colorful prime minister was not enough to compensate for his shortcomings, or overcome a catastrophic loss of party support.

multimedia.caption: “I want to tell you how sorry I am to be giving up the best job in the world,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in the statement announcing his departure, adding: “Them’s the breaks.”

title: A Whale Feeding Frenzy in Antarctica Signals a Conservation Success
abstract: Once hunted to the brink of extinction, fin whales in the Southern Ocean have rebounded and returned to their historic feeding grounds, according to a new survey.

title: Bangladesh Sees Jump in Covid Cases Before Eid Celebrations
abstract: The average number of new cases has risen to the highest since February, signaling a new wave. The country’s health system nearly collapsed in August.

abstract: The manga artist won international fame with a story that inspired a trading card game rivaling Pokemon as one of Japan’s most recognizable cultural exports.

title: What happens next?
abstract: After the latest in a series of scandals prompted a rebellion by members of his Conservative Party, Boris Johnson said he would step down. Now what?

abstract: In the capital, many Britons expressed a sense of relief after learning that the prime minister’s days were numbered.

title: Quitting Oil Income Is Hard, Even for States That Want Climate Action
abstract: Dozens of state and local budgets depend heavily on tax revenue from oil, gas and coal to fund schools, hospitals and more. Replacing that money is turning out to be a major challenge in the fight against climate change.
